Titus Center for Franchising Advisory Board Attracts Patrick McGee, MPK Equity Partners Business-Savvy Students Pair Up to Buy Franchise Titus Center - Contact Us Our Mission The Titus Center for Franchising is dedicated to empowering students and business professionals by teaching the transformative values of business format franchising. Our aim is to enhance lives and foster the development of socially-conscious communities worldwide through franchising. While our primary focus is on nurturing undergraduate talent, we are equally committed to providing comprehensive professional education to all stakeholders within the franchise sector. The center fosters strong industry relationships through networking, mentorship, and practical learning experiences. Titus Center proudly proclaims: Educating the Next Franchise Generation. Expectations for Advisory Board Members We deeply value the expertise and contributions of our Advisory Board members and have established clear expectations to ensure a mutually rewarding partnership: Engagement in Our Meetings Actively participate in at least one of our biannual meetings held in April and November, with dates communicated well in advance. Each member organization is invited to appoint two representatives to the Advisory Board to facilitate continuous engagement. Financial Partnership Commit to a financial contribution of $5,000 over two years, with a minimum annual donation of $2,500. Consider supporting additional sponsorship opportunities for Titus Center events. Sharing Expertise and Resources Provide valuable insights, tools, and strategies to support the Titus Center in achieving its mission. Collaborate with staff to assess current programs and develop new initiatives that address the evolving needs of the franchise community. Advocacy and Networking Champion the Titus Center within your professional circles and the broader franchise community. Assist in attracting top-tier franchise professionals to engage with the Center. Mentorship and Collaboration Mentor aspiring franchise students. Contribute to our goal of offering an impartial platform for franchise professionals to exchange ideas and insights. The Opportunity Joining our Advisory Board means becoming part of an influential network of franchise leaders committed to shaping the future of franchise education. Together, we can: Inspire and cultivate the next generation of franchise professionals. Drive innovation and excellence within the industry. Build communities that exemplify the social impact potential of franchising. We extend our heartfelt gratitude to our advisors for their invaluable contributions, which helps the Center achieve excellence in every aspect of our mission and advance franchise education globally. Membership Payment Portal: Each Advisory Board member company donates $2,500 annually to support the operations of Titus Center. This portal is the most efficient way to donate to Titus Center. Palm Beach Atlantic University is a 501(c)(3) organization. When you donate you will receive a receipt. Please note: Where the form asks if you’d like to give on behalf of an organization please check that box and type in Titus Center. You may use this portal for other donations to PBA and the Titus Center. We appreciate and rely on your contributions! Each member company can list two individual board members. For Membership Donations Upcoming Meetings Fall Advisory Board Meeting: Wednesday, Nov. 19, 2025 starting with breakfast at 7:30 a.m. The meeting will be on the PBA Campus in West Palm Beach. Networking Party: Nov. 18, 2025, 5:00 to 7:00 p.m. Location to be announced. Advisory Board events are for Advisory Board members and invited guests. PBA has arranged discounts with many of the hotels. Several are within walking distance to campus. Find a Hotel Schedule a meeting with Dr. Hayes to learn more Advisory Board The mission of the Titus Center for Franchising is to educate students and business professionals so that they can use franchising to better their lives as employees and/or business owners and ultimately to use franchising as a vehicle to create socially-conscious communities worldwide. While our primary focus is on recruiting and teaching undergraduate students, the Center is also committed to providing professional education for all members of the franchise sector. We expect our advisors to: Attend at least one of two meetings annually. Meetings occur in April and November and are announced well in advance. Each member company can list two team members on the Advisory Board. Contribute a financial gift of at least $5,000 over a two-year period. We ask our members to contribute a minimum of $2,500 annually. We also ask members to consider sponsoring events produced by the Center. Your annual contribution includes listing two members of your team on our board. Offer ideas, tools and resources to help the Titus Center fulfill its operational mission and its aspiration to become the “first choice” for franchise education internationally. Help the Titus Center staff evaluate its programs and provide expertise that will help the staff develop new programs to satisfy the expectations and needs of the franchise community. Advocate for the Center among colleagues and business and franchise communities with the goal of attracting the “best minds” in franchising to help the Center fulfill its mission, to provide an unbiased forum where franchise professionals can collaborate, to mentor students of franchising, and to invest in franchise education. Shaped into God's Community Book of Titus The Bible Teaching Commentary The Book of Titus: An Introduction, Map and Outline Paul J. Bucknell _________________________ Titus Outline | Titus Map | Titus Commentary (see below) Intro to Titus | Titus 1:1-4 | Titus 1:5-9 | Titus 2:1-2 | Titus 3:9-15 Purpose Titus: An Introduction, Outline And Purpose serves as the introduction to the Book of Titus in The Bible Teacher's Commentary series. Several colored diagrams are included. Introduction to Titus âFor this reason I left you in Crete, that you might set in order what remains, and appoint elders in every city as I directed you" (Titus 1:1-4). Introduction We might call ourselves the post-modern generation, a generation that is clever and knowledgeable. But we do not need to look far to find that this generation is, in fact, a very confused generation. One would think that with all this money, advanced training and specialists about that we would be more advanced, but it is not true. We agree we still have the war problem. The past generations could not eliminate that either. But how is it that we have allowed our society to be so confused as to deny what we beforehand would call the facts of life. Instead of esteeming love, beauty and faithfulness in areas like marriage, relationships and the arts, society now promotes hatred, violence, envy and unfaithfulness. Justice and courts have degenerated into influence control centers: you pay we decide. We would be fools, however, if we thought the problem was only out there, outside the church. The church has seemingly picked up the same problems. If we study the problem a bit closer, the confusion in the world is, in fact, accentuated by the confusion in the church. As the church goes, so goes the community. The church is the salt and light in the world. When the church tolerates immorality, then the society herds in that direction. When will the church learn and appreciate the power of the Gospel? We again desire the she becomes the precious and beautiful rather than the stained and worldly. Yes, we know that many people call themselves the church that is not the church at all. For them, it is only a religion. But even still, the church, the real church, has a mission and nothing could keep her back if she would only live by her calling. Why is it that segments of the church dare to lead the women from their families into the work place? Why is it that the church wants to push homosexuals into church leadership? Why is that church leaders condone and even encourage divorce as a choice of life? Whatever happened to morality and the holiness of marriage? The Apostle Paul foresaw at the end of his life a great tsunami of attacks coming against the church of God. He responded with three letters. We call them the Pastoral Epistles : 1 Timothy, 2 Timothy and Titus. After Paulâs first imprisonment, he was released. He visited different places including the island of Crete, an island only 160 miles long south of Greece and Turkey in the Mediterranean Sea. He wrote this letter to Titus around 62 A.D. from somewhere in Macedonia. Fortunately, Paul has clarified many questions regarding the place of the church in the midst of attack. If you have questions, Titus has an answer for many questions. But we must remember to ask the right questions. Sometimes, we look for answers that fit comfortably in with our lifestyles. If so, you might not be happy with the answers that you find. If the bottom line is that you want to find a church that is comfortable and fits with your standards, then you had better recognize that you are of the world. But if deep down, even though you are desperately struggling, you hope to know and please God, then you will find clear direction in this book. Even the most earnest Christian recognizes that he or she can be too affected by the world. Paul at some point had visited the island of Crete for he says in Titus 1:5 âI left you in Crete.â The church had sprung up just as it has in almost every city on this globe. God had been at work. The church grew up and informal churches started in the different cities across the island. But troubles developed. Jesus told the parable of the tares, âThe kingdom of heaven may be compared to a man who sowed good seed in his field. âBut while men were sleeping, his enemy came and sowed tares also among the wheat, and went awayâ (Matthew 13:24-25). Did you note when the enemy came and planted discord and confusion? It was when the men were sleeping. Evidently, some men were sleeping in this case too. I have come to realize that through Godâs promises we can have a wonderfully strong, church, family and individual lives. We can be effective serving. But if we let down our guard, trouble rushes in. Many of the troubles occur when we are sleeping, that is, not keeping our watch. The church at Crete faced special problems. Missionary tours are often too brief. As a result, solid churches are not established. Perhaps it was because people were not sufficiently familiar with the Word of God. It took a bit longer to raise up trusted leaders. In any case, we find Paul writing the letter of 1 Timothy to Timothy who was then stationed at Ephesus and Titus at Crete. Paulâs death was eminent. Within another year or so, he would write 2 Timothy and under Nero be martyred probably about 64 A.D. Most of BFF articles such as this one is nicely formatted for printing. Check out the great number of articles on the BFF Biblical Training Library all for one low cost . Or just order the printed copy or download of the Inductive Bible Study in Titus which comes with student handouts in pdf and .doc to edit. For Crete, however, it was time for godly leaders to be appointed. During the time of informal fellowship, Christians became prey to all sorts of self-appointed leaders and affected by their false teaching. When good leaders do not rise up, bad leaders will infiltrate and devastate the flock. Paul was exercising his apostleship by delegating Titus to appoint elders on his behalf. This letter, then, not only is a directive to Titus on how to âset the church in orderâ (verse 1:5) but also a public statement of Titusâ authority and a statement on how the church should conduct itself. In many ways, this message fits our times. Yes, we have good leaders. But as we think of the church in general, it is being chewed apart almost without even knowing it. The wolves have come in. They are picking off Christians who have made themselves separate from the church. So though there be leaders and a church body, many no longer think it important to be part of the local church. And there again, there are as many public pulpits, some of which are good and others wretched. When I was in India, I saw a Christian family watching one of these money-maker preachers. These false prophets undermine the care of the true caretakers of the flock. Discernment of these false shepherds cannot be gained because we do not know them but only hear their words. We all need the message here in this Book of Titus. We need a defining message for the church for it is from understanding who she is, that we can understand her mission. The letter is very cohesive and basically consists in advice from Paul to Titus. Key verbs mark off each chapter. Chapter 1 âset in order and appoint elders.â Chapter 2 âSpeak the things which are fitting for sound doctrine.â Chapter 3 âRemind them to be subject to rulers â¦ be ready for every good deed.â The key thought of this book, and the hope of the church is simply, âGood people do good deeds.â We need to choose good leaders to have good churches (chapter 1). We need to have godly people to be zealous for good deeds (chapter 2). We need to be reminded that our goodness comes from Christ and from that relationship grows many more good deeds (chapter 3). Of course, the opposite is true too and the church in Crete was facing a number of difficulties. They had ungodly leaders who were distorting the truth of the Gospel and creating havoc in the church. They had ungodly people who were living counter-Christian lives. They had no testimony. They had a general spirit of rebellion that, so to speak, disguised the power of the saving Gospel of Christ Jesus. Doesnât this sound much like our age? How sad. Fortunately, we have the advice from Paul to guide the church. In the outline below, please remember the original letter did not have chapters or verse numbers, but these are themes which are clearly seen as one section is compared with another. Purpose of Titus: Shaped into Godâs Community Every bride looks beautiful. But behind that veil is a woman that needs to be shaped into a woman with beautiful inner qualities. This is her life call. So it is with the bride of Christ. A calling doesnât bring all the glories of the church in a moment. She can grow. The difference is that now she belongs to Christ. God through Paul is calling the church to take significant strides closer to what she should be. Outline of Titus Shaped into Godâs Community (The Book of Titus) Three means God develops His people: A. Appoint Transformed Leaders (1:1-16) B. Cultivate Sanctified People (2:1-15) C. Teach Vibrant Gospel Truth (3:1-15) Paul affirms Titusâ authority to appoint godly leaders (Chapter 1) and instruct Godâs people in godly behavior (Chapter 2) so that they might gain a proper understanding of the gospel (Chapter 3) and as a result be a godly people who will be full of good deeds. In simpler words, we can say the purpose is to âCreate a godly people full of good deeds.â The challenge and application of Titus We have a great challenge before us. If we as Godâs people are faithful to what is said here in Titus, we will be greatly used of God to reshape the society about us. We will reflect Christâs glory more and more. As we see the glorious works of Christ worked through our lives, we will personal be enriched. This is the reason God has left this scripture for us. If we are faithful choosing right leaders, conform to Christâs calling for our lives and faithfully hold to the Gospel truths, we will see a host of good deeds coming from our lives much like the rays of the sun. Light will shine in a dark world. => Next: Titus 1:1-4 Introduction Other related articles from Biblical Foundations for Freedom : Detecting Error Inside and Outside the Church. Our mission at Titus is to help companies hire, train, and retain top talent to maximize their impact. Whether you’re looking for top talent, building high-performing teams, or optimizing your existing recruiting process, we are here to help. TITUS FROM COAST TO COAST. From day one Titus has been a remote company, however we do have offices for meetings. Ashley Drive Tampa, FL 33602 FAQs What makes Titus unique? We ditch the list of job responsibilities, instead working with our partners to uncover desired outcomes for each role. We disrupt the status quo by looking at the whole person – cognitive and behavioral abilities, passion and purpose – not just work experience. Who would I typically work with? Our partners range from small and mid-size to enterprise companies. We usually work with human resources, hiring leaders and executives directly.. How does your pricing compare to contingent recruiting firms? Our multiple billing options, no hidden fees and no outrageous finders-fee percentages makes our process a win/win for everyone. How will you work with me? There’s a reason we call our clients "partners". We believe to be successful at recruiting, we need a transparent relationship with our partners that encourages strong communication between everyone on the hiring team. We want our partners to begin and continue working with us knowing that we have their backs. Our promise and investment from day one is their satisfaction. We promise that you will be so satisfied with our partnership that you will refer us to other companies. If this is not the case, we commit to making it right. We own it, we’re honest, and we reach solutions together. What industries does Titus serve? Our team of hiring consultants are equipped to help with hard-to-fill roles across all industries. Whether your company focuses on construction, technology, healthcare, finance, or beyond, we will deliver leaders and employees for your organization whose purpose and performance aligns with your goals so you can maximize your impact. Does Titus only do recruiting? Because we are a talent strategy company, our goal is to be your partner from hire to retire. These are the key areas that we help address in any organization: employee attraction, hiring selection and onboarding, discovering and retaining high performers, team development, leadership and employee training, and employee engagement. If you don’t have an office in my location, can you still work with me? Yes. Technology is a game-changer! It does not matter where you are, you will still get the same dedicated team working on your open positions. Can Titus handle international recruitment? Shaped into God's Community Book of Titus Living Commentary Series The Book of Titus: An Introduction, Map and Outline Paul J. Bucknell _________________________ Titus Outline | Titus Map Intro to Titus 1:1-4 | Titus 1:1 Calling | Titus 1:1-3 Mission | Titus 1:4 Training | Titus 1:1-4 Bible Study Questions Purpose Titus: An Introduction, Outline And Purpose serves as the introduction to the Book of Titus in The Living Commentary series. Several colored diagrams are included. Introduction to Titus âFor this reason I left you in Crete, that you might set in order what remains, and appoint elders in every city as I directed you" (Titus 1:1-4). Introduction We might call ourselves the post-modern generation, a generation that is clever and knowledgeable. But we do not need to look far to find that this generation is, in fact, a very confused generation. One would think that with all this money, advanced training and specialists about that we would be more advanced, but it is not true. We agree we still have the war problem. The past generations could not eliminate that either. But how is it that we have allowed our society to be so confused as to deny what we beforehand would call the facts of life. Instead of esteeming love, beauty and faithfulness in areas like marriage, relationships and the arts, society now promotes hatred, violence, envy and unfaithfulness. Justice and courts have degenerated into influence control centers: you pay we decide. We would be fools, however, if we thought the problem was only out there, outside the church. The church has seemingly picked up the same problems. If we study the problem a bit closer, the confusion in the world is, in fact, accentuated by the confusion in the church. As the church goes, so goes the community. The church is the salt and light in the world. When the church tolerates immorality, then the society herds in that direction. When will the church learn and appreciate the power of the Gospel? We again desire the she becomes the precious and beautiful rather than the stained and worldly. Yes, we know that many people call themselves the church that is not the church at all. For them, it is only a religion. But even still, the church, the real church, has a mission and nothing could keep her back if she would only live by her calling. Why is it that segments of the church dare to lead the women from their families into the work place? Why is it that the church wants to push homosexuals into church leadership? Why is that church leaders condone and even encourage divorce as a choice of life? Whatever happened to morality and the holiness of marriage? The Apostle Paul foresaw at the end of his life a great tsunami of attacks coming against the church of God. He responded with three letters. We call them the Pastoral Epistles : 1 Timothy, 2 Timothy and Titus. After Paulâs first imprisonment, he was released. He visited different places including the island of Crete, an island only 160 miles long south of Greece and Turkey in the Mediterranean Sea. He wrote this letter to Titus around 62 A.D. from somewhere in Macedonia. Fortunately, Paul has clarified many questions regarding the place of the church in the midst of attack. If you have questions, Titus has an answer for many questions. But we must remember to ask the right questions. Sometimes, we look for answers that fit comfortably in with our lifestyles. If so, you might not be happy with the answers that you find. If the bottom line is that you want to find a church that is comfortable and fits with your standards, then you had better recognize that you are of the world. But if deep down, even though you are desperately struggling, you hope to know and please God, then you will find clear direction in this book. Even the most earnest Christian recognizes that he or she can be too affected by the world. Paul at some point had visited the island of Crete for he says in Titus 1:5 âI left you in Crete.â The church had sprung up just as it has in almost every city on this globe. God had been at work. The church grew up and informal churches started in the different cities across the island. But troubles developed. Jesus told the parable of the tares, âThe kingdom of heaven may be compared to a man who sowed good seed in his field. âBut while men were sleeping, his enemy came and sowed tares also among the wheat, and went awayâ (Matthew 13:24-25). Did you note when the enemy came and planted discord and confusion? It was when the men were sleeping. Evidently, some men were sleeping in this case too. I have come to realize that through Godâs promises we can have a wonderfully strong, church, family and individual lives. We can be effective serving. But if we let down our guard, trouble rushes in. Many of the troubles occur when we are sleeping, that is, not keeping our watch. The church at Crete faced special problems. Missionary tours are often too brief. As a result, solid churches are not established. Perhaps it was because people were not sufficiently familiar with the Word of God. It took a bit longer to raise up trusted leaders. In any case, we find Paul writing the letter of 1 Timothy to Timothy who was then stationed at Ephesus and Titus at Crete. Paulâs death was eminent. Within another year or so, he would write 2 Timothy and under Nero be martyred probably about 64 A.D. Most of BFF articles such as this one is nicely formatted for printing. Check out the great number of articles on the BFF Biblical Training Library all for one low cost . The special study Inductive Bible Study in Titus comes with student handouts in pdf and .doc to edit. A printed copy or download can be ordered. For Crete, however, it was time for godly leaders to be appointed. During the time of informal fellowship, Christians became prey to all sorts of self-appointed leaders and affected by their false teaching. When good leaders do not rise up, bad leaders will infiltrate and devastate the flock. Paul was exercising his apostleship by delegating Titus to appoint elders on his behalf. This letter, then, not only is a directive to Titus on how to âset the church in orderâ (verse 1:5) but also a public statement of Titusâ authority and a statement on how the church should conduct itself. In many ways, this message fits our times. Yes, we have good leaders. But as we think of the church in general, it is being chewed apart almost without even knowing it. The wolves have come in. They are picking off Christians who have made themselves separate from the church. So though there be leaders and a church body, many no longer think it important to be part of the local church. And there again, there are as many public pulpits, some of which are good and others wretched. When I was in India, I saw a Christian family watching one of these money-maker preachers. These false prophets undermine the care of the true caretakers of the flock. Discernment of these false shepherds cannot be gained because we do not know them but only hear their words. We all need the message here in this Book of Titus. We need a defining message for the church for it is from understanding who she is, that we can understand her mission. The letter is very cohesive and basically consists in advice from Paul to Titus. Key verbs mark off each chapter. Chapter 1 âset in order and appoint elders.â Chapter 2 âSpeak the things which are fitting for sound doctrine.â Chapter 3 âRemind them to be subject to rulers â¦ be ready for every good deed.â The key thought of this book, and the hope of the church is simply, âGood people do good deeds.â We need to choose good leaders to have good churches (chapter 1). We need to have godly people to be zealous for good deeds (chapter 2). We need to be reminded that our goodness comes from Christ and from that relationship grows many more good deeds (chapter 3). Of course, the opposite is true too and the church in Crete was facing a number of difficulties. They had ungodly leaders who were distorting the truth of the Gospel and creating havoc in the church. They had ungodly people who were living counter-Christian lives. They had no testimony. They had a general spirit of rebellion that, so to speak, disguised the power of the saving Gospel of Christ Jesus. Doesnât this sound much like our age? How sad. Fortunately, we have the advice from Paul to guide the church. In the outline below, please remember the original letter did not have chapters or verse numbers, but these are themes which are clearly seen as one section is compared with another. Purpose of Titus: Shaped into Godâs Community Every bride looks beautiful. But behind that veil is a woman that needs to be shaped into a woman with beautiful inner qualities. This is her life call. So it is with the bride of Christ. A calling doesnât bring all the glories of the church in a moment. She can grow. The difference is that now she belongs to Christ. God through Paul is calling the church to take significant strides closer to what she should be. Outline of Titus Shaped into Godâs Community (The Book of Titus) Three means God develops His people: A. Appoint Transformed Leaders (1:1-16) B. Cultivate Sanctified People (2:1-15) C. Teach Vibrant Gospel Truth (3:1-15) Paul affirms Titusâ authority to appoint godly leaders (Chapter 1) and instruct Godâs people in godly behavior (Chapter 2) so that they might gain a proper understanding of the gospel (Chapter 3) and as a result be a godly people who will be full of good deeds. In simpler words, we can say the purpose is to âCreate a godly people full of good deeds.â The challenge and application of Titus We have a great challenge before us. If we as Godâs people are faithful to what is said here in Titus, we will be greatly used of God to reshape the society about us. We will reflect Christâs glory more and more. As we see the glorious works of Christ worked through our lives, we will personal be enriched. This is the reason God has left this scripture for us. If we are faithful choosing right leaders, conform to Christâs calling for our lives and faithfully hold to the Gospel truths, we will see a host of good deeds coming from our lives much like the rays of the sun. Light will shine in a dark world. => Next: Titus 1:1-4 Introduction Other related articles from Biblical Foundations for Freedom : Detecting Error Inside and Outside the Church.
